Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Novel Rapid Non-destructive Cell Culture Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to evaluate the commercial potential of a rapid non-destructive cell culture platform based on polymer textures that change shape by adjusting the temperature. Cell culture is a common activity in medicine and research in which cells are taken from a source, such as a patient, and put into a culture dish to multiply. A challenge in this activity is to remove the attached cells from the cell culture dish for further use. If cells remain attached for too long and overpopulate the surface they die, so they have to be regularly transferred to a new dish. The current most popular method of removing them from a dish uses a chemical dissolving agent which dissociates them but also damages or kills the cells. Afterward, cells have to be rinsed and need about a day to recover before they can be used or studied. It's only done this way because currently, there isn't a better alternative. The motivation for this project is driven by the need for greater reproducibility in laboratory testing of human cells. This technology is important in the advancement of stem cell research/therapies, eliminating animal testing for pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and consumer products, as well as other medical-related areas which use culture of cells. The proposed technology is significant because it allows for a faster and non-destructive option for culturing cells as compared to current technologies available in the market place.

To evaluate the commercial potential of the proposed technology, a rapid non-destructive cell culture platform, this team will engage in direct conversations with potential customers and trade partners to determine what is considered innovation in the cell culture market, identify a market-supported price to acquire this innovation, and develop an effective market activation strategy. The potential impact for this technology in several markets using cell culture is: $170 billion market for stem cell related activities and a $14.7 billion total cell culture market (2013) which is estimated to grow to $24.5 billion by 2018. Product development activities will consist of investigating rapid device fabrication, validation of release and viability with various cell types including stem cells, and developing non-confluent cell release. Development of this technology into a commercial product could positively impact the speed and accuracy with which cell culture is performed. The resultant advances in stem cell research and clinical tests can lead to faster diagnosis, cure, and management of disease in humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central aim of our project was to evaluate the commercial potential of a rapid non-destructive cell culture platform based on thermo-responsive shape-memory polymers.

The NSF I-Corps award and our participation in the training program enabled our team to address the three key objectives proposed in our project plan, namely, (1) determining what is considered innovation by cell culture customers, (2) determining a market-supported price to acquire this innovation, and (3) determining an effective market activation strategy. Over the course of the training program, our team initiated three major pivots based on the 115+ customer interviews conducted.

Early on, we pivoted to a new business hypothesis focused on a specific customer segment – those needing to isolate or handle sensitive cells – because cell culture customers with these specific needs indicated they would enthusiastically adopt a product that removes cells without physical scraping or enzymatic digestion. Our second pivot was that the price of our product should be based on a fraction of the economic pain resolved for these unique customers. Our third pivot was to target contract research organizations and rapid growth biotech companies as key partner and/or client segments.

At the end of the program, we reached a “Not Yet” decision as were not ready for commercialization; then in the following months, we focused on continued exploration of the market for our technology, and we conducted further research on the aspects of the technology that customers indicated were important. A patent was applied for and is pending which addresses the specific features that customers asked for. Currently, prototype development continues under the PI and Co-PI, and commercialization of the technology is being led by the Industry Mentor. 

This award provided an immersive entrepreneurial experience and training for a graduate student, as the Entrepreneurial Lead. In addition, funds partially supported the doctoral training of 4 doctoral students in projects related to this commercialization grant. These students conducted research on biomaterials surface modifications that can influence cell adhesion and release, and were immersed in a training program that included career and technical expertise development. 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2017
Modified by: Nathan D Gallant
